Graham Hogg. So... Graham Hogg is a Scots. So Hoggy, how did you first get into Carnival?
Carnival? Well... How did I first get into Carnival? Well I suppose I was... I got into... I'm a stilt
walker and most of my contact with Cardiff Carnival has been as a stilt performer,
dancer, whatever. And I went to Bristol to study circus in the late 80s and I...
in the 80s there's like a big kind of like weird alternative circus scene sort of
kicking off. A lot of connections with travellers and things like travellers were
painting their buses and becoming circuses and in that era full-time was
non-accredited so it was much more independent, running their own courses,
their own kind of tutors and their own style of doing things and really good
mix. It was really good scene. It was in St Paul's and when I went there I know I
studied a bit of everything, bit of clowning and mass work, juggling and all these things
and no one was doing stilts at all. Literally the stilts were the wooden stilts
you held on there in the cupboard. No one was interested in them whatsoever and
I've been doing... I've done some stilts actually previous to that when I lived in
Wales actually. I lived in Mid Wales and lived in in Hengindob Wells and there was a
street theatre group there called What the Dickens, called Chris Orenzella.
They still have a Dickens festival every year.
Well the Victorian festival, I lived in Hengindob Wells and that festival would
happen. I saw it like you know probably five years and I was just a you know a

kind of proper street busker. Very limited skills, very basic

generating a sort of pattern for the crowd which is a kind of formula with what
street stuff follows really and has followed since. So anyway, so Kenzie
